summary: The KGB (Komitet Gosudarstvennoy Bezopasnosti, or Committee for State Security) was the main security agency for the Soviet Union. In the context of the JFK assassination documents, the KGB is primarily investigated for any potential involvement with Lee Harvey Oswald during his time in the Soviet Union and later in Mexico City. The documents explore whether Oswald was an agent of the KGB, if the KGB had any interest in him, or if they were aware of his intentions. The documents also cover KGB defectors like Yuriy Nosenko and their information regarding Oswald and KGB operations. Surveillance of KGB officials, such as Nikolay Sergeyevich Leonov and Valeriy Vladimirovich Kostikov, and their activities in relation to Soviet and Cuban operations are also investigated. The documents also reveal CIA operations to monitor KGB activities, recruit potential assets, and gather intelligence on Soviet operations and personnel.
significance: The KGB's significance in the JFK assassination context lies in the possibility of Soviet involvement, either directly or indirectly, through Lee Harvey Oswald. The documents aim to determine if Oswald was acting under KGB direction or influence, or if the KGB had any prior knowledge of his plans. The investigation into KGB defectors and their testimonies is crucial in assessing the credibility of claims regarding Soviet involvement. The surveillance of KGB officials and their contacts in Mexico City is also significant in understanding potential connections between Oswald and Soviet intelligence.
